key_points: Hurricane Ida was the most expensive climate-change disaster of 2021, costing $65 billion and claiming 115 lives.
Ida resulted in extreme weather across multiple U.S. states, including deadly winds in Louisiana and floods in New York.
The top 10 climate-change disasters of 2021 amounted to at least $170 billion in costs.
2021 saw a 13% increase in financial costs from global natural disasters compared to 2020.
Texas experienced a severe ice storm in February, resulting in over 111 deaths and financial losses exceeding $20 billion.
2021 is expected to be the sixth time global natural catastrophes crossed the $100 billion insured loss threshold since 2011.
Swiss Re estimated $250 billion in damages from natural and extreme weather events in the past year, a 24% increase over the previous year.
The frequency, intensity, and cost of natural disasters are increasingly linked to climate change.
The Christian Aid report highlights the difficulty in tabulating losses in underinsured nations or those with poor record-keeping.
The U.N. climate summit in Glasgow made progress on cutting methane emissions and saw increased private-sector involvement in climate action.
spokespersons: Steve Bowen (Meteorologist, head of catastrophe insight at insurer Aon)
